channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: India Train Crash: Up to 230 Dead and 900 Injured in Odisha
item.description: The accident, in the eastern state of Odisha, was among the worst ever in a nation with a history of rail safety problems.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky, Mike Ives and Mujib Mashal

item.title: Spy Deaths on Boat in Italy Ignite Conspiracy Theories
item.description: Four people died when a storm sank a boat in northern Italy. Then it emerged that 21 of those aboard had worked for Israeli or Italian intelligence, igniting a speculative frenzy.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo and Ronen Bergman
item.media:description: Recovery operations on Lake Maggiore, Italy, on Monday for the sunken boat, which officials said had been hired to celebrate a birthday.

item.title: She Lost Her Career, Family and Freedom. She’s Still Fighting to Change Iran.
item.description: Fighting for change has cost Narges Mohammadi her career, separated her from family and deprived her of liberty. But a jail cell has not succeeded in silencing her.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Narges Mohammadi at her home in Tehran last year during a medical furlough from prison.

item.title: Remains Match Traits of Missing Call Center Workers in Mexico, Officials Say
item.description: A grisly discovery in western Mexico this week has become a stark reminder of the fate of the country’s tens of thousands of disappeared people.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:description: Forensic experts with several bags of human remains that were extracted from the bottom of a ravine by a helicopter on Wednesday in Zapopan, Jalisco State, Mexico.

item.title: As War Persists in Ukraine, Doctors Warn of Rise in Premature Births
item.description: The mental burden of Russia’s invasion has exacted a heavy toll on civilians. As the fighting drags on, pregnant women are among those facing the toughest trials.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times

item.title: After Mass Shootings in Serbia, Few Want to Give Up Their Guns
item.description: Two massacres have prompted the government to tighten already strict rules, but the nation’s gun culture is deep-rooted and complex.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Vladimir Zivojinovic for The New York Times
item.media:description: A vigil in the Serbian capital, Belgrade, after a deadly school shooting in May. Patchy enforcement of gun laws has left a large number of weapons illegally in private hands.

item.title: Senegal Blocks Some Social Media After Ousmane Sonko Is Sentenced
item.description: Demonstrators battled with the police to protest a two-year prison sentence given to a leading opposition figure. At least nine people died in the confrontations.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:description: Demonstrators clash with riot policemen at a neighborhood in Dakar, Senegal, on Friday.

item.title: Deaths of 2 Women and a Girl Outside a Locked Bomb Shelter Shake War-Weary Kyiv
item.description: Outside the children’s clinic-turned-bomb-shelter, residents asked the question haunting Ukraine’s capital: Who was responsible for the locked door that left women and children seeking safety exposed to a missile strike?
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Blinken Details Russia’s ‘Failures’ in Ukraine and Warns Against Cease-Fires
item.description: A speech by the U.S. Secretary of State struck a triumphal tone, while also warning against a rush to short-term solutions to the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Antony J. Blinken, the U.S. secretary of state, speaking on Friday at Helsinki’s City Hall in Finland.

item.title: Russian Missiles Kill 3 in Kyiv, Including Mother and 9-Year-Old Girl
item.description: They were among three people killed in a Russian missile attack, officials said. Ukraine opened an investigation, as Russians described shelling and evacuations in border regions.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emergency workers and the mother of a woman killed in an overnight missile strike in Kyiv, Ukraine, stand near the body on Thursday.

item.title: U.K. Government Refuses to Give Boris Johnson’s Texts to Covid Inquiry
item.description: A panel examining how Britain handled the pandemic wants copies of the former prime minister’s text messages, but the government is taking the matter to court.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Boris Johnson, the former British prime minister, leaving home in London in March.

item.title: Conflict With the Far Right Shrouds Jerusalem’s Pride Parade
item.description: Much of Israel’s L.G.B.T.Q. community feels threatened by the right-wing government and its judicial overhaul plan — even with a gay speaker of Parliament.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Participants dancing at the Pride parade in Jerusalem on Thursday.

item.title: Ben Roberts-Smith, Australia’s Most Decorated Soldier, Loses Defamation Case
item.description: A judge ruled for newspapers that had been accused of defaming the soldier by reporting that he had committed war crimes in Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Ben Roberts-Smith in Sydney last year.

item.title: Ukraine Investigates Deaths by Shelter as Russia Evacuates Border Towns
item.description: In Ukraine’s capital, residents struggled with the question of who was to blame for a shelter closed off to two women and a child. In Russia, the authorities described evacuations in a border region.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mourner on Friday paying her respects in Kyiv, Ukraine, for a girl who was killed in a Russian bombardment when she and her mother tried but failed to get inside a bomb shelter.

item.title: U.S. Will Try to Bring China Into Arms Control Talks
item.description: The nuclear order established during the Cold War is under more stress than at any point since 1962, but efforts to negotiate with Beijing are unlikely to succeed anytime soon.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and David E. Sanger
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Oliver Contreras for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jake Sullivan, the national security adviser, described President Biden’s plans to deal with nuclear threats in a post-Cold War world.

item.title: Ukrainian Recruits, Wanting to Fight, Train in the U.K. for Counteroffensive
item.description: “We’re going to die, probably,” one recruit said bluntly, as he trained on Friday with several hundred others at a military camp in Yorkshire, England.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers take part in urban combat exercises at a British Army military base in Northern England on Friday.

item.title: Analyzing Shiv’s Decision on ‘Succession’ With a Feminist Text
item.description: Still grappling with the finale of the hit HBO series? An article by a feminist theorist could be surprisingly helpful with understanding the deals that patriarchal systems offer women.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Matthew Macfadyen and Sarah Snook in the “Succession” series finale.

item.title: Ukrainian Shelling in Russia’s Belgorod Region Forces Evacuations
item.description: ‘The conditions are quite difficult,’ the local governor of the region said on social media.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev

item.title: The Three Other Trump Investigations
item.description: The Manhattan case isn’t Trump’s only legal problem.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Donald Trump raises his fists to supporters after a rally campaigning for GOP presidential nomination in Manchester, NH on April 27, 2023.

item.title: Sparrows Are the Main Suspects in a Bird-Nest Murder
item.description: A nest was assaulted. Was it the cowbird or the sparrow?
item.dc:creator: Daryln Brewer Hoffstot

item.title: Alli Smith, of the Cornell Ornithology Laboratory, offers beginner tips for exploring the wide world of birds.
item.description: Alli Smith, of the Cornell Lab of Ornithology, offers beginner tips for exploring the wide world of birds.
item.dc:creator: Camille Baker
item.media:credit: Kirsten Luce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Indigo Goodson took up birding during the pandemic and now goes everywhere with “binoculars in tow,” she said. “My friends get annoyed.”

item.title: Big, Incredible Journeys in an Incredibly Big Country
item.description: Trips across Australia are often necessarily trips at a striking scale.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Ukraine’s and Sweden’s bids to join NATO.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said that his country was “ready to join NATO.”

item.title: Eusebius McKaiser, Acerbic South African Political Analyst, Dies at 44
item.description: Adamantly progressive, openly gay and politically fearless, he cast a sharp eye on the country’s post-apartheid politics and culture.
item.dc:creator: Alan Cowell
item.media:credit: Oupa Bopape/Gallo Images, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Eusebius McKaiser traced many of South Africa’s social problems to the apartheid era, and wrote about them for South Africans and a broader Western audience.

item.title: With a New, Improved ‘Einstein,’ Puzzlers Settle a Math Problem
item.description: Earlier this spring, tiling aficionados thought maybe they’d found the shape of their dreams. Now they’re certain.
item.dc:creator: Siobhan Roberts

item.title: Ukraine’s Future Ties to NATO Are Main Topic as Western Nations Meet
item.description: The question of how to guarantee Ukrainian security loomed over a meeting of NATO foreign ministers in Norway and a gathering of European leaders in Moldova.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken speaking in Oslo on Thursday.

item.title: Arizona Limits Construction Around Phoenix as Its Water Supply Dwindles
item.description: In what could be a glimpse of the future as climate change batters the West, officials ruled there’s not enough groundwater for projects already approved.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle and Jack Healy
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times
item.media:description: Queen Creek, Ariz., a suburb of Phoenix, is projected to grow to 175,000 people from its current 75,000 — if it can find enough water.

item.title: Biden Makes Case for Global Alliances at Air Force Academy Commencement
item.description: President Biden said cooperation with allies had helped the United States confront challenges to stability around the world.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: “You are the very embodiment of American military excellence,” President Biden told Air Force Academy graduates on Thursday. “You are ready for anything — anything.”

item.title: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on Warring Sudanese Factions
item.description: The measures came a day after Sudan’s military pulled out of peace talks in the Saudi city of Jeddah that aimed to stop the fighting.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Declan Walsh
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Smoke rising in Khartoum in May, during clashes between the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces and the Sudanese army.

item.title: China Wants to Set the Terms of Any ‘Thaw’ With the U.S.
item.description: China has pushed to set the terms of its re-engagement with the Biden administration, rebuffing a request for a defense meeting while urging Washington to drop sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Hong
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Beijing rejected an invitation for China’s defense minister, Li Shangfu, to meet with Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III at a security meeting this weekend in Singapore.

item.title: Protests Erupt in Senegal After Opposition Leader Is Sentenced to Prison
item.description: At least one person died in clashes after Ousmane Sonko, a strong rival to the president, was sentenced in absentia to two years in a trial that many Senegalese considered politically motivated.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:description: Protests broke out across Senegal after an opposition leader was convicted and sentenced in a trial that some Senegalese considered politically motivated.

item.title: The House Passed the Debt Limit Bill. Who Won?
item.description: President Biden both won and lost the debt-ceiling negotiation.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Speaker Kevin McCarthy and President Biden.

item.title: Zelensky Pushes for EU and NATO Membership at Meeting in Moldova
item.description: “This year is for decisions,” President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said at the European Political Community gathering, which sought to showcase Western solidarity amid the Kremlin’s war.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine and President Maia Sandu of Moldova arriving at the European Political Community summit in Bulboaca, Moldova, on Thursday.

item.title: What It Takes to Protect Kyiv From Russian Bombardment
item.description: Russian air attacks on Kyiv have come in relentless waves. Yet very little has penetrated the patched-together but increasingly sophisticated air defense network. Here’s why.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian servicemen demonstrated working on a mobile air defense system responsible for protecting a patch of sky just outside Kyiv.

item.title: Iceland Is a Magnet for Tourists. Its First Lady Has Some Advice for Them.
item.description: Eliza Reid, a former U.N. tourism ambassador and the wife of President Gudni Johannesson, welcomes her country’s many visitors, and has a few suggestions on safety, respect and how to meet locals.
item.dc:creator: Paige McClanahan

item.title: China Investing in Open-Source Intelligence Collection on the U.S.
item.description: A new report outlines Chinese efforts to mine public information from the Pentagon, think tanks and private companies to gain insight on the American military.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: American service members flying a Navy reconnaissance plane over the South China Sea in 2018.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Russia’s response to drone strikes on Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Some of the apartment buildings damaged after a drone attack in Moscow.

item.title: Russia Strikes Kyiv, Killing 3 in Another Early Morning Attack
item.description: Russia has recently increased the pace and intensity of its strikes on the Ukrainian capital.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Nicole Tung and Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emergency personnel at a clinic compound in Kyiv, Ukraine, after a Russian attack on Thursday.

item.title: The struggle for control of the Arctic looms as Blinken tours NATO’s north.
item.description: Russia may be having major difficulties in Ukraine, but it remains a vast power in the north and the Arctic, where climate change is opening new sea routes for trade and trouble.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: The missile cruiser Peter the Great, part of the Russian Navy’s northern fleet, at its Arctic base in Severomorsk in 2021. Russia, China and the West are all seeking to expand their military presence in the Arctic.

item.title: Individual Canadian Cigarettes to Be Labeled With Health Warnings
item.description: Tobacco companies must soon label individual cigarettes sold in the country with a health warning, in what Canada is calling a global first.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai

item.title: Russia Denounces West Over Drone Strike on Moscow
item.description: Kremlin officials said Ukraine’s allies should have condemned the strike, and argued again that its real war was with the West.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: Police officers stood outside several apartment buildings damaged after a drone attack in Moscow on Tuesday.

item.title: Rishi Sunak Is Still Haunted by Boris Johnson and Liz Truss
item.description: Boris Johnson’s misadventures still make headlines, but Prime Minister Rishi Sunak’s bigger problem is high inflation and soaring bond yields reminiscent of those that toppled Liz Truss.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain leaving 10 Downing Street this month.

item.title: U.S. Adds Aid to Ukraine to Deliver Ammunition for Drones and Artillery
item.description: The move to send $300 million in additional support comes as Moscow has come under drone attacks in recent days.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers with a Stinger anti-aircraft missile near a frontline position in Donetsk last year.

item.title: As Iran Seizes Tankers, UAE Pulls Back From US-Led Maritime Force
item.description: The United Arab Emirates announced it had stopped participating in the security group after Iran seized two tankers in the Persian Gulf recently.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Aboard the U.S.S. Abraham Lincoln in the northern Arabian Sea, in 2019.

item.title: Readers in Asia: What Does L.G.B.T.Q. Life Look Like Where You Live?
item.description: We may include your response in a June edition of the Asia Pacific Morning Briefing.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:description: Pride in Chennai, India, last June.

item.title: Fear Sets In Among Turkey’s L.G.B.T. Community After Erdogan’s Attacks
item.description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan vilified gay people during his re-election campaign, calling them a threat to society and rallying conservatives against them. It has left people feeling threatened, and alone.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard, Elif Ince, Safak Timur and Sergey Ponomarev
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:description: Drag artists applying makeup before a performance in a club in Istanbul in May.

item.title: Climate Change and Russia Spell Trouble for NATO Up North
item.description: Russia may be having major difficulties in Ukraine, but it remains a vast power in the north and the Arctic, where climate change is opening new sea routes for trade and trouble.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: The missile cruiser Peter the Great, part of the Russian Navy’s northern fleet, at its Arctic base in Severomorsk in 2021. Russia, China and the West are all seeking to expand their military presence in the Arctic.

item.title: How to Lower Deaths Among Women? Give Away Cash.
item.description: Mortality rates fell by 20 percent among women in countries that began cash transfer programs to the poor. Children also benefited.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Omar Havana for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mother and her 1-year-old son in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. The new analysis collected information on cash transfer programs and death rates in 37 countries.

item.title: Germany Closes Four of Its Five Russian Consulates After Moscow Dispute
item.description: Berlin responds to the Kremlin limiting the number of German diplomatic staff allowed in Russia.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: The Russian Embassy in Berlin will remain open, while four of its five consulates in Germany will be forced to close.

item.title: Sudan’s Army Withdraws From Cease-Fire Talks
item.description: The move deals a blow to efforts to end the war and deliver humanitarian aid to millions of people nationwide.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Yemenis who fled Sudan disembarked from the Saudi ship Abha at Jeddah port in May.

item.title: Female Wrestlers in India Threaten to Toss Olympic Medals in Protest
item.description: Their protest dispersed, female wrestlers who have accused a powerful official of sexual harassment went to the Ganges intending to throw away their Olympic medals.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal, Hari Kumar and Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: Vinesh Phogat, center, and other wrestlers clashed with the police as they tried to march to the new Parliament building on Sunday in New Delhi.

item.title: Honeybee Swarms Darken U.K. Skies, Sending Beekeepers Scrambling
item.description: It’s swarming season in Britain, with honeybee colonies splitting in half in search of new homes. This year, beekeepers say they are getting an unusually high number of swarm sightings.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Ian Campbell, via The British Beekeepers Association
item.media:description: A swarm of bees collected at St. Francis church in Newcastle upon Tyne, England.

item.title: A Big Day for the Debt Ceiling
item.description: The bipartisan debt limit deal still isn’t assured of passing.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Speaker of the House Kevin McCarthy, R-Calif. Speaks following his meeting with President Joe Biden in the Oval Office early last week.

item.title: German Court Convicts 4 Leftists in Attacks Targeting Neo-Nazis
item.description: A 28-year-old woman and three accomplices were sentenced to prison for their roles in a series of attacks on people they considered neo-Nazis.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Lina E., second from right, and three co-defendants covered their faces during a court hearing in Dresden, Germany, on Wednesday.

item.title: Israel Called Them ‘Precision’ Strikes. But Civilian Homes Were Hit, Too.
item.description: Palestinians in Gaza say that Israel’s strikes against Islamic Jihad amount to a collective punishment aimed at making them fearful about who their neighbors might be.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Samar Abu Elouf
item.media:description: A hole left by a bomb that entered the home of the Khoswan family, in a strike on an Islamic Jihad member who lived below, in Gaza City.

item.title: Triggered by North Korea, South Korea’s False Evacuation Alert Causes Chaos
item.description: South Koreans said the alert, which was triggered by a North Korean rocket launch, showed that their country was unprepared to respond to a real emergency.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun, Victoria Kim and Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: Watching a news broadcast with file footage of the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, at the Seoul Railway Station in Seoul on Wednesday.

item.title: India Will Scrap 2,000 Rupee Notes, Echoing 2016 Demonetization
item.description: The move to retire 2,000-rupee notes, worth $24, has triggered bad memories of a similar campaign in 2016. It has also left some businesses short of change.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir and Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Sanchit Khanna/Hindustan Times, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Customers exchanging 2,000-rupee notes at a bank in New Delhi last week.

item.title: State Farm Stops Offering Insurance in California
item.description: The largest insurer in California said it would stop offering new coverage. It’s part of a broader trend of companies pulling back from dangerous areas.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle, Jill Cowan and Ivan Penn
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: A firefighter tried to save a home in Meyers, Calif., in 2021.

item.title: Ireland Worries That Brexit Will Ruin Fishing Industry
item.description: Along Ireland’s coast, fishing has been a way of life for generations. But changes to the industry — including a cut in quotas after Brexit and a government plan to scrap boats — may see a way of life disappear.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Finbarr O’Reilly
item.media:description: A crew member aboard the fishing vessel Aquila in April on its final voyage.

item.title: Pakistan Courts Challenge Military With High-Profile Rulings
item.description: Long seen as kowtowing to the military, the judiciary has defied it in recent rulings, signaling an important shift in Pakistan’s political landscape.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Salman Masood
item.media:description: Paramilitary soldiers in front of the Supreme Court during a ruling on former Prime Minister Imran Khan, in Islamabad, Pakistan, earlier this month.
